refsynopsisdiv.para: eventd is using three differente types of configuration files: global, event and action files.
The files are searched in these directories in the following order:

listitem.para: In user mode (the default): $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/&PACKAGE_NAME; (fallback to ~/.config/&PACKAGE_NAME;/)
In system mode: /etc/&PACKAGE_NAME;
$EVENTD_CONFIG_DIR (see eventd1)

refsynopsisdiv.para: These paths are standard paths. Actual paths may depend on your configuration, see eventd -P output.

refsect2.title: Global configuration file
refsect2.para: The global configuration file is named &PACKAGE_NAME;.conf.
Each file found in the configuration directories is parsed one after the other, so the latest file can override settings in a preceding one.

refsect2.title: Event and action files
refsect2.para: The event and action files can be extended via a configuration key (see ).
If the same file is found in several places, the last one is used.
File concatenation is done after each directory was searched for files, so you can override them.
eventd will also walk through subdirectories, to let you organize your events.

para.emphasis: An event file is mandatory for the event to be processed by eventd.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: eventd configuration files use a Key=Value syntax, organized in categories. Categories are specified using square brackets (e.g. [Category Name]). List values are semi-colon-separated (';'). More details are available in the XDG Desktop Entry Specification.

refsect2.title: Global configuration file
refsect2.para: This file is passed to every plugin so they can read their global configuration too.
Sections read in these files are identified as “Global sections”.

refsect2.title: Event files
refsect2.para: Event files describes the events that the daemon will recognise when an event collection plugin will push it.
These files are only ever read by eventd itself.
They define a list of action ids that eventd (and its plugins) should trigger when a matching event fires up.
Unknown action ids are silently ignored. If an event ends with an empty action list, it is discarded.
Sections read in these files are identified as “Event sections”.

refsect2.title: Action files
refsect2.para: Action files describes the actions that the plugins may do when dispatching an event. Each action can itself trigger subactions.
eventd itself reads very little information in there, but plugins can read as much as they want to determine their exact behaviour when the action is triggered.
Official action plugins require at least their own configuration section to do something. They have no “catch-all” action.
Sections read in these files are identified as “Action sections”.

refsect1.title: Configuration key types
refsect1.para: Each key can be of a specified type. Basic types are integer, boolean or string, sometimes constrained like milliseconds or percentage.
For positives numeric types, -1 may be allowed to mean infinity.
For strings, a localised version may be used and will be indicated as such.
For lists, items are separated by a semicolon (';'). You can optionally end the list with a semicolon too.

refsect2.title: Enumeration
refsect2.para: An enumeration is a string which can take a limited set of values. Values are case-insensitive.
Accepted values depend on the key and will be listed in the relevant key descriptions.

refsect2.title: Format strings
refsect2.para: A format string can contain references to event data.

Please note that the config file format uses the backslash (\) for escaping sequences. Therefore, you will have to escape it if it is needed in your format string (e.g. to uses backreferences in the replacement part of the regex syntax).

refsect2.title: File URI
refsect2.para: A file URI is a string that can be either a data name or a format string of an URI scheme.
In the former case, the data is searched in the event, and then either parsed as an URI or used directly if it is a GVariant of type "(msmsay)" containing the MIME type, the charset, and the data.
Three URI schemes are supported: file:// theme: and data: (Base64 extension only, charset and mime type may be ignored).

refsect2.title: Other types
refsect2.para: More specific types are described in the relevant key description.

refsect1.title: Configuration ids and event matching
refsect1.para: When eventd receive an event from one of its event collecting plugin, it searches the best match, using the following mechanism:

listitem.para: event will first try to get a list of possible matches basde on event’s category and name:
eventd will get the list of matches for both the category and the name of the event
If the list is empty, eventd will get the list matches for the category the event
If the list is still empty, the event is unknown and will not be dispatched.
event will then test all possible matches to find the best one.
If one of them matches, trigger its actions, otherwise continue
If none of them matches, the event is unknown and will not be dispatched.

refsect1.para: Multiple events can match the name and the category. eventd provides a fine-grained matching mechanism. Several keys are dedicated to that. See .

The path to the TLS certificate file.

The path to the TLS private key file.
If not specified, the certificate file is expected to contain the key.
A string
The name that the server will publish using DNS-SD.

A convenience key to set the $G_TLS_GNUTLS_PRIORITY environment variable.

A list of names that will be used to discover [Relay name] sections.

The form is name:port.
If you omit port or use 0, the SRV DNS record &EVP_SERVICE_TYPE;.host will be used to find the real host and port to connect to.

refsect2.title: Section [File]
refsect2.para: This section if for file inclusion. It allows a more customised management of your files.

listitem.para: A file name
Prepend the specified file to this one.

refsect2.title: Section [Event category name sub-name]
refsect2.para: This is the main event configuration section. It contains the core related settings.
The category and name are used to match the event while sub-name is only meant to differentiate sections and is not used anywhere in eventd.
You can use an empty name to have data matches on a whole category. This means the category and the sub-name will be separated with two spaces.

listitem.para: A list of data names
All data listed here must exist for this event id to match.
A list of (data name,regex) tuples
If the named data is present, it must match the provided regex. All present data must match for this event id to match.
A list of flag names
eventd will only dispatch an event if all of these flags are present.
A list of flag names
eventd will only dispatch an event if none of these flags is present.
An integer (can be negative)
The less you put here, the more important this event configuration is. It allows you to order alternative configurations, as the first matching configuration is taken.
If you only have Category and/or Name keys, the default value is .
If you have more precise matching keys, the default value is then .
A boolean
If true, the event is not dispatched.
A list of action names
The list of actions to trigger when the event fires up.
See .

refsect2.title: Section [Action]
refsect2.para: This section allows to identify the action uniquely and link it to subactions if wanted.

listitem.para: An action name
This name can be used in the Subactions= key of this section or the Actions= key of the [Event] section.
A list of action names
The list of sub actions to trigger.
